stem: How can arc blow be reduced during SMAW?

choices.text: Lengthen the arc and increase current
Shorten the arc, move the work lead, or backstep
Switch to a larger electrode only
Weld only in one direction

rationales.CHOICE-2: Short arcs and better return lead placement reduce magnetic arc blow.

stem: What arc length is generally recommended for SMAW?

choices.text: Very long arc for better visibility
As short as practical, about the electrode diameter
Exactly 1 inch
No effect on quality

rationales.CHOICE-2: Short arcs improve shielding and reduce spatter and undercut.

stem: For SMAW, which is a recommended arc start method on finished surfaces?

choices.text: Strike directly on visible faces
Strike on run‑on tabs or within joint area
Strike on machined faces away from joints
No preference

rationales.CHOICE-2: Start within joint/tabs to avoid hard spots on faces.

stem: Why remove slag between passes with E7018?

choices.text: It is optional; slag burns out
To avoid slag inclusions and lack of fusion
To cool the joint
To increase arc length

rationales.CHOICE-2: Slag can become trapped and prevent bonding on subsequent beads.

stem: What problem can damp E7018 electrodes cause?

choices.text: Improved penetration
Porosity and delayed cracking
Lower hydrogen content
Faster travel speed

rationales.CHOICE-2: Moisture in the coating adds hydrogen to the weld pool.

stem: Which polarity is commonly used with E6010?

choices.text: DCEN
DCEP
AC only
Either AC or DCEN

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cellulosic E6010 typically runs on DCEP for deep penetration.

stem: Which technique is typical for open‑root welding with E6010?

choices.text: Steady drag with no motion
Whip‑and‑pause to control the keyhole
Fast weave to wash the toes
Backhand push 45°

rationales.CHOICE-2: Whipping controls the keyhole and allows root fusion without excessive burn‑through.

stem: In the designation E7018, what does the '70' indicate?

choices.text: 70% joint efficiency
70 A recommended current
70,000 psi minimum tensile strength
70° included bevel angle

rationales.CHOICE-3: The first two digits give the minimum tensile strength in ksi.

stem: What coating type characterizes E7018 electrodes?

choices.text: Acid
Basic low‑hydrogen
Rutile
Cellulosic

rationales.CHOICE-2: E7018 is a basic (low‑hydrogen), often iron‑powder type electrode.

stem: Which power source setting can E7018 typically run on?

choices.text: DCEN only
DCEP or AC, per manufacturer
AC only
DCEP only, never AC

rationales.CHOICE-2: E7018 is usually suitable for DCEP and often AC depending on brand/WPS.

stem: Which statement describes E7024 electrodes?

choices.text: Cellulosic coating, deep penetration
High‑deposition iron‑powder rutile, flat/horizontal
Basic low‑hydrogen for all positions
Stainless steel welding only

rationales.CHOICE-2: E7024 is iron‑powder rutile for high deposition in flat/horizontal.

stem: What are typical angles for a flat fillet weld with SMAW?

choices.text: Work angle ~45° with 5–15° travel angle
Work angle 15° with 45° travel angle
90° to both pieces with zero travel angle
Push 30° into the joint

rationales.CHOICE-1: A 45° work angle with a slight drag/push travel angle is common.

stem: What hazard is associated with welding galvanized steel?

choices.text: No special hazard compared to bare steel
Zinc fumes; remove coating locally and ensure ventilation
Helium leaks from pores
Aluminum oxide deposits

rationales.CHOICE-2: Zinc fumes are hazardous; remove coatings where possible and ventilate adequately.

stem: Why should E7018 electrodes be kept in a heated rod oven between uses?

choices.text: To increase flux melting rate
To prevent moisture pickup and hydrogen cracking
To make slag removal easier
To reduce amperage requirements

rationales.CHOICE-2: Dry storage limits hydrogen pickup that can cause cold cracking.

stem: Which electrode is best suited for deep‑penetration open‑root welding on rusty steel?

choices.text: E308L

rationales.CHOICE-3: Cellulosic E6010 provides deep penetration and tolerance to light surface contamination.

stem: What does the '1' in E7018 indicate?

choices.text: Flat position only
Flat and horizontal only
All positions
Overhead only

rationales.CHOICE-3: The position digit '1' means the electrode is usable in all positions.

stem: What is the main benefit of preheating thick or high‑strength steel before welding?

choices.text: It increases residual stress
It reduces cooling rate and hydrogen cracking risk
It eliminates the need for interpass cleaning
It strengthens the flux coating

rationales.CHOICE-2: Preheat slows cooling and allows hydrogen to diffuse, lowering crack risk.

stem: What is a good practice when restarting a SMAW bead?

choices.text: Strike on the weld face and continue
Grind/feather the stop and restart slightly ahead to tie in
Restart exactly in the crater
Do nothing; the slag will float out

rationales.CHOICE-2: Feathering and restarting ahead allow blending without defects.

stem: Which condition commonly leads to undercut in SMAW?

choices.text: Excessive travel speed or a long arc
Low travel speed with short arc
Small electrode diameter
Using stringer beads

rationales.CHOICE-1: High speed or long arc washes metal away from the toes, creating undercut.

stem: Which technique helps control heat when welding vertical‑up with E7018?

choices.text: Wide fast weave
Stringer beads (or limited weave) with pauses at the toes
Downhand travel with high current
Hold a long arc

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stringers with brief toe pauses help keep the puddle under control.

stem: What safe starting current should you choose for E7018 Ø3.2 mm (1/8 in) in the flat position on an 8 mm fillet weld?

rationales.CHOICE-2: For 1/8 in E7018 a typical range is ~90–130 A; start mid‑range and adjust by puddle response.

stem: Open‑root butt with ~3 mm gap. What starting current for E6010 Ø3.2 mm (DCEP)?

choices.text: Any — just go by sound

rationales.CHOICE-2: For 1/8 in E6010, 80–110 A is typical — controllable keyhole without burn‑through.

stem: How should you finish a bead to avoid a crater crack?

choices.text: Snap the arc off sharply at the end
Raise current and ‘shoot’ out of the crater
Fill the crater with a short backstep/small circle, then break the arc smoothly
Extinguish the arc on the base metal

rationales.CHOICE-3: Filling the crater before breaking the arc prevents a shrinkage crack at the bead end.

stem: Before welding through tack welds, what should you do to them?

choices.text: Nothing — the slag will burn out
Grind the tacks flush and feather their edges
Increase current and burn straight through the tacks
Leave as is — it will strengthen the weld

rationales.CHOICE-2: Flush‑grinding and feathering prevent slag entrapment and give a smooth tie‑in for the main pass.

stem: Vertical‑up (3F) T‑joint 10 mm with E7018. Which travel pattern is preferred?

choices.text: Wide fast weave
Small ‘triangle’/‘Christmas tree’ with brief pauses at the toes
Straight stringer with no pauses
Large figure‑eights in the middle

rationales.CHOICE-2: A small triangle with toe pauses holds the puddle and builds even shelves.

stem: On a vertical E7018 weld you get undercut on the upper toe. First corrective action?

choices.text: Lengthen the arc to ‘cool’ it
Slightly reduce current, shorten the arc, and pause at the upper toe
Travel even faster
Switch to a larger electrode

rationales.CHOICE-2: Short arc, a brief toe pause, and moderate current reduce undercut on the top edge.

stem: Overhead (4F/4G) with E7018. What helps hold the puddle?

choices.text: Raise current and use a wide weave
Use a smaller diameter, keep a short arc, and run short stringers
Push the electrode 30° forward
Hold a long arc so it ‘cools’

rationales.CHOICE-2: Smaller diameter, short arc, and short passes minimize dripping and sag in overhead.

stem: WPS limits interpass temperature to ≤200 °C. How do you correctly monitor it on the part?

choices.text: By gloved hand feel
Temperature crayon/contact thermometer on base metal 25–50 mm from the weld toe
Measure on the slag immediately after the pass
Aim a pyrometer at a shiny face with no emissivity correction

rationales.CHOICE-2: Measure the base metal near the weld; slag/‘touch’ checks are unreliable.

stem: A box of E7018 sat outside the rod oven for 5 hours at ~20 °C. What should you do?

choices.text: Use immediately — 5 hours is trivial
Warm the tip with a flame and weld
Return the batch for rebake/storage per manufacturer; scrap/rebake any suspect electrodes
Coat with oil to ‘seal’ moisture out

rationales.CHOICE-3: Low‑hydrogen rods have limited ‘open‑time’; if exceeded, rebake per data sheet or replace.

stem: Typical E7018 rebake (after moisture pickup) and subsequent holding regime:

choices.text: 80–100 °C for 10 min; store at room temperature
120–150 °C for 1 h; store at 40 °C
~315 °C (±25°) for ≈1 h; then hold at 120–150 °C
500 °C for 4 h; store at 250 °C

rationales.CHOICE-3: Rule of thumb: rebake around 315 °C, then hold 120–150 °C; follow the brand/WPS specifics.

stem: Butt joint, 25 mm carbon steel shows cold (hydrogen) cracking. Practical fix:

choices.text: Increase current and speed
Add preheat ~100–150 °C and control interpass temperature per WPS
Use a smaller electrode diameter
Gap to 10 mm and weld with no preheat

rationales.CHOICE-2: Preheat reduces cooling rate and crack risk; control interpass per WPS.

stem: After an E6010 root, a E7018 ‘hot pass’ is planned. What must be done first?

choices.text: Nothing — the slag will float out
Remove all slag/scale to bright metal and verify root fusion
Raise E7018 current and melt the slag out
Spray a chlorinated solvent for cleaning

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cellulosic slag residues cause lack of fusion and ‘wagon tracks’; clean fully before the hot pass.

stem: A 1.2 m fillet on thin section is warping badly. How can you reduce distortion?

choices.text: Make one continuous pass
Use short stitch welds with backstep/symmetric sequence
Max out current and travel speed
Water‑quench immediately after each stitch

rationales.CHOICE-2: Short stitches and backstep/symmetry spread heat input and limit distortion.

stem: Where should the work (return) clamp be attached for SMAW?

choices.text: To a bearing housing near the weld
To an oxygen cylinder — the path is short
To the workpiece as close as practicable to the weld area
To a building steel column for convenience

rationales.CHOICE-3: Clamp to the work near the weld, avoiding current paths through bearings/cylinders/structures.

stem: Sheet 3 mm with E6013: how to avoid burn‑through on a fillet?

choices.text: Use 4.0 mm electrode and high current
Use 2.5 mm electrode, low‑end current, short arc, and short ‘pecking’ stringers
Hold a long arc and go slow
Make a very wide weave to spread heat

rationales.CHOICE-2: Smaller diameter, lower current, and short arc reduce heat input on thin material.

stem: After a vertical‑up E7018 pass you see ‘wagon tracks’ of slag along the toes. What should you adjust?

choices.text: Raise current further
Lengthen the arc
Add brief toe pauses, slightly reduce current, and improve interpass cleaning
Travel faster with no pauses

rationales.CHOICE-3: Toe pauses and cleaning prevent slag traces trapped along bead edges.

stem: You need high deposition on an 8 mm fillet in flat/horizontal. Which E7018 diameter is a good choice?

choices.text: 5.0 mm (3/16 in) — in any position

rationales.CHOICE-3: Ø4.0 mm offers higher deposition in flat/horizontal while remaining manageable.

stem: In the flat position with E7018 you typically travel by…

choices.text: Pushing 20–30° forward
Dragging with a 5–10° back angle
Holding the rod perfectly perpendicular
Any way — it doesn’t matter

rationales.CHOICE-2: A slight drag angle is common for 7018 — steadier puddle and slag control.

stem: Your electrode holder is running hot; the jaws burn every 2–3 rods. What should you do?

choices.text: Wrap with tape and continue
Greatly lower current and ‘stretch’ the rods
Check/tighten the cable connection and repair/replace the holder
Periodically wet the holder with water

rationales.CHOICE-3: Poor contact/worn jaws cause heating and voltage drop — service or replace the holder and fix the cable lug.

stem: You’re unsure about the dryness of E7018 from an open container. Practical step:

choices.text: If the coating looks shiny, they’re dry
Use a fresh pack from the oven; return the suspect batch for rebake per datasheet and check batch/date
Heat the tips to red with a torch
Dip the tip in oil for ‘protection’

rationales.CHOICE-2: When in doubt, weld with verified dry rods and rebake or replace the open batch per instructions.

stem: What starting current should you choose for E7018 Ø4.0 mm (5/32 in) in the flat position on an ~10 mm fillet?

rationales.CHOICE-2: For Ø4.0 mm E7018 a common range is ~130–180 A; start mid‑range and tune by puddle response.

stem: You only have an AC transformer. You need an open‑root on slightly rusty steel. What should you choose?

choices.text: E6010 on DCEN
E6011 on AC
E7018 on AC with no prep
E7024 on AC with a wide weave

rationales.CHOICE-2: E6011 is designed for AC and tolerates light contamination — suitable for roots.

stem: During an E6010 root the keyhole became too large and unstable. First corrective action?

choices.text: Increase current and whip wider
Slightly reduce current, shorten the arc, and use a smaller whip‑and‑pause
Switch to E7018 right in the root
Force the rod into the opening aggressively

rationales.CHOICE-2: Less heat and a short arc stabilize the keyhole and prevent burn‑through.

stem: Bevel and root gap are out of WPS tolerance (gap ~5 mm vs 2–3 mm). Proper action?

choices.text: Compensate with higher current and a wide weave
Stop and correct the prep/gap or use a permitted backing method per WPS
Knock off tacks on one side only
Lay a wide cap over it and continue

rationales.CHOICE-2: Nonconformances to the WPS are corrected before welding — fix fit‑up or apply an approved backing.

stem: Your multipass weld has excessive reinforcement (a high cap). How do you prevent this on the next sections?

choices.text: Greatly lengthen the arc
Slightly reduce current/weave amplitude and increase travel speed; use stringers
Peen the reinforcement with a hammer
Make mid‑bead stops to cool the puddle

rationales.CHOICE-2: Lower heat input and stringer beads help form a flatter cap without overlaps.

stem: On a horizontal fillet you see overlap along the lower toe. What should you adjust first?

choices.text: Reduce speed further and lengthen the arc
Slightly increase speed/current, keep a short arc, and hold the correct angle toward the lower toe
Switch to a larger electrode
Push the electrode 30° forward

rationales.CHOICE-2: Overlap is excess metal without fusion; a short arc, proper angle, and enough energy into the toe eliminate it.

stem: Near the end of the weld at a corner you get magnetic arc blow. What can you do on site without changing the power source?

choices.text: Lengthen the arc and raise current
Move the work clamp closer to the end, run a short arc, and use short stitches/backstep
Change to the largest electrode diameter
Only weld in one direction

rationales.CHOICE-2: Short current paths and a short arc reduce magnetic effects; backstep helps stabilize the puddle.

stem: Outdoor wind and your E7018 cap shows porosity. First step?

choices.text: Increase current and speed
Shield the area from wind and verify dry electrodes/clean edges
Lengthen the arc to ‘cool’ it
Move the work clamp to another part

rationales.CHOICE-2: Wind, moisture, or dirt cause pores — screen the weld, use dry rods, and ensure clean metal.

stem: WPS: interpass ≤250 °C. You measured 270 °C. What’s correct?

choices.text: Let it air‑cool or blow with air to below the limit, then continue
Water quench for fast cooling
Continue but reduce current by 20%
Do nothing — within measurement error

rationales.CHOICE-1: Cool naturally/with air until within spec; water quenching is not permitted.

stem: What is a typical ‘holding’ temperature for low‑hydrogen electrodes in a jobsite oven?

choices.text: Room temperature

rationales.CHOICE-2: E7018 are commonly held ~120–150 °C; follow the brand datasheet/WPS.

stem: Inverter settings: ‘Hot Start’ and ‘Arc Force’ for E7018 vertical‑up. Preferred approach?

choices.text: Hot Start minimum, Arc Force maximum
Disable both features
Moderately raise Hot Start and Arc Force, watching the puddle and toes
Hot Start maximum, Arc Force minimum

rationales.CHOICE-3: Moderate boosts ease ignition and puddle control without causing undercut.

stem: Long butt: how should you place tack welds to minimize distortion and keep the root gap?

choices.text: Sparse, long tacks every 300–400 mm
Short, even tacks every 75–150 mm with a symmetric sequence
One long tack along the whole seam
Tacks only at the beginning and end

rationales.CHOICE-2: Frequent short tacks hold alignment and the gap uniformly.

stem: A common sequence for a 10 mm V‑groove with no backing is:

choices.text: A single wide E7018 weave from the start
E6010 root → hot pass → fill with stringers → E7018 cap
E6013 root only and clean
Cap first, then root

rationales.CHOICE-2: Typical practice: a cellulosic root followed by low‑hydrogen fill and cap.

stem: How do you correctly verify an 8 mm fillet weld size with a fillet gauge?

choices.text: Lay the gauge on the bead and eyeball it
Use the 8 mm leaf so both legs and the face contact the gauge with no light gap
Measure the bead diagonal with a tape
Measure only one leg on one side

rationales.CHOICE-2: Full contact on both legs and face without daylight confirms the fillet size.

stem: WPS requires DCEP for E7018, but you welded a section on AC (the brand allows AC). What should you do?

choices.text: Leave it — the rod can run on AC
Consult the responsible engineer; if out of WPS, remove and re‑weld on DCEP
Just lay a DCEP cap over it without removal
No documentation needed — not critical

rationales.CHOICE-2: The WPS governs; deviations require evaluation and typically repair to the specified polarity.

stem: Overhead (4G) open‑root with E6010: you get periodic burn‑throughs. What helps first?

choices.text: Increase current and dwell over the keyhole
Slightly reduce current, shorten the arc, reduce whip amplitude; a copper backing is acceptable
Hold a long arc so it ‘cools’
Switch to E7024

rationales.CHOICE-2: Lower heat and a small whip stabilize the root; copper backing can help in overhead.

stem: Joint edges are painted/oily. Proper prep for SMAW?

choices.text: Raise current by 20% and burn through contaminants
Clean to bright metal 10–20 mm each side and degrease with an approved solvent
Do nothing — the cap will cover it
Coat heavily with machine oil for protection

rationales.CHOICE-2: Clean, dry metal reduces porosity and defects; do not ‘burn off’ contaminants.

stem: 2F (horizontal fillet). How should you hold the electrode to counter gravity and avoid undercut?

choices.text: Work angle ~45°, 5–10° drag travel angle, slight lean toward the upper member
Perfectly perpendicular with no angle
Push 30° downward toward the lower member
Use a wide fast weave across both legs

rationales.CHOICE-1: A small lean toward the upper piece with a slight drag angle stabilizes the puddle in 2F.

stem: You find a ‘hi‑lo’ (misalignment) of ~2 mm; WPS allows ≤1 mm. What should you do?

choices.text: Compensate with higher current and ‘fill’ it
Break tacks/re‑fit or dress edges to meet the WPS tolerance
Shift the bead axis with a wide weave
Do nothing — the cap will level it

rationales.CHOICE-2: Fix misalignment before welding or between passes; do not ‘fill’ geometry errors.

stem: Inspection found a slag inclusion in the fill. Proper repair?

choices.text: Lay an additional cap over it
Gouge/grind to sound metal and re‑weld per WPS
Heat with a torch to melt the inclusion
Leave it — not critical

rationales.CHOICE-2: Remove the defect to sound metal and re‑weld in accordance with the procedure.

stem: The arc feels soft and unstable: total welding lead length is ~40 m and current is 140 A. What should you do first?

choices.text: Add another 20 m of lead — more length is fine
Install a step-up transformer on the output
Increase cable cross-section or double up the leads, shorten the run, and move the power source/work clamp closer
Simply raise current by 30–40 A

rationales.CHOICE-3: Voltage drop on long/thin leads chokes the arc; fix by larger conductors and shorter return path.

stem: A supply extension cord was left coiled on its reel; the cord runs hot and the arc sags. What’s the proper action?

choices.text: Nothing — that’s normal while welding
Fully uncoil the reel and verify the cord gauge is adequate
Wrap the reel in foil to cool it
Add a second extension cord in series

rationales.CHOICE-2: Coiled cords overheat and cause voltage drop; uncoil fully and use proper gauge.

stem: E6010 struggles on an inverter: hard starts and the arc dies. Practical fix?

choices.text: Switch to DCEN and lengthen the arc
Enable the cellulosic/6010 mode or raise Arc Force (Dig), or use E6011 instead
Lower OCV to the minimum
Use a larger-diameter electrode at the same current

rationales.CHOICE-2: Many inverters need a special 6010 profile or higher Dig; E6011 is more forgiving on standard inverters.

stem: Open-root E6010 without backing: after the root you see ‘icicles’ on the backside. How should you correct technique on the fly?

choices.text: Increase current and whip wider
Slightly reduce current, shorten the arc, and reduce whip amplitude
Hold a long arc to ‘cool’ the puddle
Force the rod aggressively into the keyhole

rationales.CHOICE-2: Backside icicles indicate excess heat/metal; a short arc and smaller whip stabilize the keyhole.

stem: After an E6010 root you see small ‘dog-ears’ at the edges. Before a E7018 hot pass you should:

choices.text: Melt them out with E7018 without cleaning
Feather the edges lightly by grinding and remove slag to bright metal
Spray anti-spatter and weld
Do nothing — the hot pass will wash it out

rationales.CHOICE-2: Feathering and thorough cleaning help avoid lack of fusion and ‘wagon tracks’.

stem: After cooling you find a crater crack on a vertical E7018 weld. Proper repair?

choices.text: Lay an extra bead over it ‘for strength’
Gouge/grind the crack out to sound metal and re‑weld per WPS
Torch-heat and peen it closed
Leave it if the crack is small

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cracks must be removed to sound metal and re‑welded; capping over a crack is unacceptable.

stem: 2G (horizontal groove) with E7018: the bead sags and you get undercut at the top toe. What should you adjust?

choices.text: Increase weave width and current
Lean slightly toward the upper toe, add short toe pauses, and keep a short arc
Push the rod 30° downward
Hold a long arc to reduce heat

rationales.CHOICE-2: A slight lean toward the upper member with brief toe pauses stabilizes the puddle and prevents undercut.

stem: Your electrode stuck to the work. How do you free it without damaging the machine or the work?

choices.text: Jerk the holder sharply
De‑energize/release current, twist the rod, and gently break it free
Hammer the holder against the work until it lets go
Splash water on the stick point

rationales.CHOICE-2: First remove current, then twist/break off to avoid damaging contacts or the work.

stem: Before bend tests on a plate coupon, what should be done to the weld and specimens?

choices.text: Leave reinforcement as is — stronger
Grind reinforcement flush, remove backing (if any), and break edges/deburr the specimens
Oil‑polish the face for ‘slip’
Cut a V‑groove down the center to act as a notch

rationales.CHOICE-2: For valid bends, remove cap/root reinforcement, remove backing, and dress sharp specimen edges.

stem: You welded with a backing bar. How should it be removed and prepared for NDE/testing?

choices.text: Knock it off with a sledge — fastest
Burn it off with a torch along the seam
Remove mechanically and grind the root to a smooth surface without notches or undercut
Leave it — it won’t affect results

rationales.CHOICE-3: Remove backing carefully and finish to a smooth, notch‑free surface for reliable inspection.

stem: A tack on the root cracked under heat. What should you do before continuing?

choices.text: Place another tack right over it
Remove the cracked tack completely and install a new correctly sized tack
Weld over it — the crack will fuse out
Close the gap and weld without tacks

rationales.CHOICE-2: Cracked tacks must be removed and replaced; otherwise the defect propagates into the root.

stem: You used magnetic squares for fit‑up. Near the end the arc is blowing off. What should you do?

choices.text: Leave the magnets — they hold alignment
Remove the magnets before welding that section, move the work clamp closer, and run a short arc
Lengthen the arc and raise current
Switch to a larger electrode diameter

rationales.CHOICE-2: Magnets exacerbate arc blow; remove them, shorten the current path, and keep a short arc.

stem: Arc strikes were found outside the weld zone on low‑alloy steel. Proper corrective action?

choices.text: Cover with a cap bead
Grind to sound metal, perform NDE (PT/MT) if required, and document per procedure
Peen the marks with a hammer
Paint over before inspection

rationales.CHOICE-2: Arc strikes can create hard spots; remove to sound metal and verify per quality procedure.

stem: Outdoor work at −10 °C on 20 mm carbon steel with E7018. Which set of measures is correct?

choices.text: Weld as usual but faster
Minimal preheat on the first pass only
Preheat per WPS, wind shielding, interpass temperature control, and a heated rod quiver
Raise current by 30% with no preheat

rationales.CHOICE-3: Cold conditions speed cooling and raise H‑crack risk; use preheat, wind shields, interpass control, and dry rods.

stem: A continuous line of pores appears along the cap. Likely cause and action?

choices.text: Weave too narrow — widen it
Anti‑spatter/oil contamination — degrease to bright metal and verify dry electrodes
Current too low — increase by 50%
Arc too short — lengthen it

rationales.CHOICE-2: Linear porosity often comes from contamination or moisture; clean thoroughly and use dry 7018.

stem: After the root you detect local lack of fusion. Proper repair before fill passes?

choices.text: Cover it with fill — it won’t be seen
Back‑gouge/air‑carbon gouge to remove the defect and re‑weld the root
Lay a wide bead over the area
Torch‑heat and ‘burn in’ the spot

rationales.CHOICE-2: Remove lack‑of‑fusion defects to sound metal (often by back‑gouging) and re‑establish a sound root.

stem: Tight access inside a box section; E7018 Ø4.0 mm doesn’t fit well and the puddle wanders. Practical solution?

choices.text: Leave as is — tolerances will allow it
Switch to a smaller diameter (3.2/2.5 mm), run short stringers, and keep a short arc
Lengthen the arc and widen the weave
Add oil for ‘better glide’

rationales.CHOICE-2: Smaller diameter and short stringers improve control in cramped spaces.

stem: On vertical E7018 you see undercut and a harsh arc. The inverter’s Arc Force (Dig) is set high. What should you do?

choices.text: Increase Arc Force further
Reduce Arc Force to a moderate level and keep a short arc with toe pauses
Switch to a long arc
Greatly increase current

rationales.CHOICE-2: Excessive Dig can wash metal from the toes; moderate settings and proper technique reduce undercut.

stem: Pipe joint: internal hi‑lo is ~1.5 mm; the WPS allows ≤1 mm. What should you do before welding?

choices.text: Shift bead axis with a wide weave and ‘fill it’
Use hi‑lo clamps/line‑up tools to re‑fit within tolerance, then weld
Do nothing — the hot pass will cover it
Increase the root gap to 6 mm and weld without correction

rationales.CHOICE-2: Correct misalignment mechanically during fit‑up; you can’t ‘fill away’ geometry errors.

stem: Two welders work on the same structure at once on different seams. Stray currents cause arc strikes and hot spots. Practical solution?

choices.text: Attach both work leads to a nearby column
Provide separate return leads for each station and clamp on the workpiece near each arc
Use a single common work lead — simpler
Place magnets near the weld to stabilize the arc

rationales.CHOICE-2: Separate, short return paths clamped close to each weld prevent stray current through the structure.
